case_name: First Income-tax Officer v. Short Brothers Private Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 97 of 1965 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 97 of 1965. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated October 3, 1963 of Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 1242 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 3, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 1242 of 1962.

facts.text: Ms. Short Brothers Private Ltd. sold its coffee estates and other assets on December 24, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On December 24, 1959, M s. Short Brothers  Private  Ltd. sold its companyfee estates and other assets, and by

facts.text: By resolution dated February 6, 1960, Ms. Short Brothers Private Ltd. resolved to be voluntarily wound up and liquidators appointed.

anchor.surface_text: and by resolution, dated February 6, 1960, it was resolved that it be voluntarily wound up and liquidators be appointed to administer its affairs.

facts.text: Liquidators distributed Rs. 8,50,000 to shareholders on March 30, 1960 from proceeds of asset sale.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the proceeds realized by sale of its assets, the liquidators of the Company distributed on March 30, 1960 Rs. 8,50,000 to the shareholders.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Salem informed liquidators by letter dated December 19, 1960 that Rs. 8,50,000 distributed is treated as dividends and to pay tax under S. 18(3D).

anchor.surface_text: By letter, dated December 19, 1960, the Income-tax Officer, Salem, informed the liquidators that he proposed to treat that amount distributed as dividends in the hands of the shareholders, and to call upon the liquidators to pay the amount of tax deductible under S. 18 3D  of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Liquidators submitted that amount was capital appreciation from sale of agricultural lands and buildings, not liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The liquidators submitted that the amount distributed to the shareholders was capital appreciation realised by sale of agricultural lands and buildings of the Company, and was number liable to tax,

facts.text: Liquidators argued amounts were current profits of the year of winding up resolution, not dividend under S. 2(6A)(c).

anchor.surface_text: and that in any event the amounts distributed represented current profits of the year in which it was resolved that the Company be wound up and were on that account number dividend within the meaning of S. 2 6A  c  of the Incometax Act.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Salem ordered on October 18, 1962 liquidators to pay Rs. 4,11,700 retained from distribution.

anchor.surface_text: After some companyrespondence the Income-tax Officer, Salem by his order, dated October 18, 1962, finally called upon the liquidators to pay Rs. 4,11,700 which was retained by the liquidators from the distribution made to the shareholders.

facts.text: Liquidators filed Writ Petition No. 1242 of 1962 in Madras High Court for writ of prohibition against ITO enforcing collection.

anchor.surface_text: The liquidators then moved the High Court of Judicature at Madras, for a writ of prohibition restraining the First Income-tax Officer from taking further action to enforce companylection of the amount referred to by him in his companymunication, dated October 18, 1962.

facts.text: Madras High Court issued writ restraining ITO from enforcing tax demand, as demand not in conformity without determining capital gains from ag lands.

anchor.surface_text: Holding that the demand made by the Income-tax Officer was number in companyformity with the law in that the amount of Rs 8,50,000 which had been distributed companyld number be deemed to be distributed as dividend without determining whether any portion of the amount represented capital gains, which arose out of the sale of capital assets companysisting of lands from which agri- cultural income was derived, the High Court issued a writ restraining the Income-tax, Officer from enforcing the demand for tax.

facts.text: High Court reserved liberty to ITO to examine question afresh and determine correct dividend under S. 2(6A)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court reserved liberty to the Income-tax Officer to examine the question afresh, and to determine the companyrect amount of dividend within the meaning of S. 2 6A  c .

facts.text: First Income-tax Officer appealed to Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave, the First Income-tax Officer has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: ITO submitted High Court bypassed assessment machinery under Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted on behalf of the Income-tax Officer that the High Court in entertaining the petition in its extra- ordinary jurisdiction under Art. 226 of the Constitution, bypassed the machinery of assessment and rectification of orders of assessment prescribed by the Indian Income-tax Act which is both adequate and efficacious.

facts.text: High Court held accumulated profits include profits till date of winding up resolution under S. 2(6A)(c) and Explanation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that all profits accumulated in the previous years and the profits till the date on which it was resolved that the Company be voluntarily wound up would be included in the expression accumulated profits under s. 2 6A   c  of the Indian Income-tax Act read with the Explanation.

facts.text: High Court held capital gains taxable under S.12B except excepted period are dividend when distributed, but ag land profits not capital gains hence not dividend.

anchor.surface_text: They held that even capital gains taxable under S. 12B except for the period mentioned in the Explanation were when distributed, dividend within the definition, but profits realised by transfer of property used for agricultural purposes and which yielded agricultural income number being capital gains taxable under the law are number dividend,

facts.text: Counsel for liquidators contended all profits in year of voluntary winding up not taxed as dividend under S.2(6A)(c).

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the liquidators companytended in the first instance that all profits whatever may be their character arising in the year in which the Company is voluntarily wound up are number liable to be taxed as they did number fall within the definition of dividend in S. 2 6A  c .

facts.text: Counsel for Department contended entire Rs. 8,50,000 liable as dividend under S.12 regardless of source.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Department while supporting the view of the High Court relating to the chargeability to tax of current profits, companytended that the entire amount of Rs. 8,50,000 distributed to the shareholders, whatever may be the source from which the profits were earned, was liable to be brought to tax under S. 12 of the Income-tax Act as dividend distributed.

facts.text: S.2(6A)(c) defines dividend as distribution on liquidation attributable to accumulated profits immediately before liquidation.

facts.text: Explanation to S.2(6A)(c) excludes capital gains arising before April 1, 1946 or after March 31, 1948 and before April 1, 1956 from accumulated profits.

issues.text: Whether the High Court was justified in entertaining the writ petition under Article 226 of the Constitution despite the availability of adequate and efficacious alternative remedies under the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted on behalf of the Income-tax Officer that the High Court in entertaining the petition in its extra- ordinary jurisdiction under Art. 226 of the Constitution, bypassed the machinery of assessment and rectification of orders of assessment prescribed by the Indian Income-tax Act which is both adequate and efficacious.

issues.text: Whether profits earned till the date of the resolution for voluntary winding up (current profits) are included in 'accumulated profits immediately before its liquidation' under Section 2(6A)(c) of the Income-tax Act and thus constitute dividend on distribution.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that all profits accumulated in the previous years and the profits till the date on which it was resolved that the Company be voluntarily wound up would be included in the expression accumulated profits under s. 2 6A   c  of the Indian Income-tax Act read with the Explanation.

issues.text: Whether capital gains arising outside the excepted periods specified in the Explanation to Section 2(6A)(c) are included within 'accumulated profits' for the purpose of deeming distributions on liquidation as dividend.

anchor.surface_text: Explanation.-The expression accumulated profits wherever it occurs in this clause, shall not include capital gains arising before the 1st day of April, 1946, or after the 31st day of March, 1948, and before the 1st day of April, 1956.

issues.text: Whether capital appreciation realised from the sale of lands from which agricultural income is derived (not taxable as capital gains under Section 12B read with Section 2(4A)) would, on distribution to shareholders on liquidation, be liable to tax as dividend under Section 2(6A)(c) and Section 12 of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question which remains to be considered is whether capital appreciation in respect of the lands from which the income derived is agricultural income and which was not taxable in the hands of the company as capital gains would still on distribution be liable to be taxed as dividend under s. 12 of the Income-tax Act.

holdings.text: The question however is one of discretion of the High Court and not of its jurisdiction, and if the High Court in exercise of its discretion thought that the case was one in which its jurisdiction may be permitted to be invoked, this Court would normally not interfere with the exercise of that discretion.

anchor.surface_text: The question however is one of discretion of the High Court and not of its jurisdiction, and if the High Court in exercise of its discretion thought that the case was one in which its jurisdiction may be permitted to be invoked, this Court would normally not interfere with the exercise of that discretion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 226 confers discretionary jurisdiction on High Court to issue writs despite alternative remedies; Supreme Court does not interfere with such discretion.

holdings.text: The contention raised by counsel for the Company that the profits earned in the current year i.e., the year in which it was resolved that the Company be wound up, were not dividend within the meaning of S. 2(6A)(c) of the Act cannot be accepted.

anchor.surface_text: The contention raised by counsel for the Company that the profits earned in the current year i.e., the year in which it was resolved that the Company be wound up,were not dividend within the meaning of S. 2 6A   c  of the Act cannot be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.2(6A)(c) includes accumulated profits immediately before liquidation, encompassing current profits up to that point; legislative amendments of 1955/1956 clarify inclusion; distinguishes prior cases like Burrell and Sheth Haridas.

holdings.text: The Explanation plainly implies that within the expression accumulated profits are included capital gains outside the excepted periods.

anchor.surface_text: By the Explanation to S. 2 6A accumulated profits include capital gains not arising within the excepted period. The Explanation is undoubtedly couched in negative form, but there is no ground for accepting the argument of counsel that in the substantive clauses of the definition, accumulated profits do not include capital gains. The Explanation plainly implies that within the expression accumulated profits are included capital gains outside the excepted periods.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Negative phrasing of Explanation to S.2(6A)(c) implies inclusion of capital gains arising outside specified periods in accumulated profits.

holdings.text: Profits derived by transfer of lands from which the income derived is agricultural income would not therefore be chargeable on a combined reading of s. 12B with s. 2(4A) of the Income-tax Act under the head capital gains... Unless, therefore, appreciation in the value of capital assets is included in the capital gains, distribution by the liquidator of the rise in the capital value will not be deemed dividend for the purpose of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Profits derived by transfer of lands from which the income, derived is agricultural income would not therefore be chargeable on a combined reading of s. 12B with s. 2(4A) of the Income- tax Act under the head capital gains The expression accumulated profits does not include capital gains arising within the excepted periods vide Explanation to s. 2 6A .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agricultural lands excluded from capital assets under S.2(4A); profits therefrom not capital gains under S.12B, hence not accumulated profits or dividend under S.2(6A)(c); realization of capital appreciation not treated as business profits.

precedents.case_name: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. George Burrell
precedents.cited_proposition: undivided profits of past years and current year profits distributed in liquidation are not liable to super-tax as they cease to be profits and become assets only
precedents.cited_holding: liquidator turns assets into money and divides among shareholders proportionally; surplus trading profits treated as capital, not to be split into capital and income retrospectively

anchor.surface_text: By the Explanation to S. 2 6A accumulated profits include capital gains not arising within the excepted period. The Explanation is undoubtedly couched in negative form, but there is no ground for accepting the argument of counsel that in the substantive clauses of the definition, accumulated profits do not include capital gains. The Explanation plainly implies that within the expression accumulated profits are included capital gains outside the excepted periods.

The question however is one of discretion of the High Court and number of its jurisdiction, and if the High Court in exercise of its discretion thought that the case was one in which its jurisdiction may be permitted to be invoked, this Court would numbermally number interfere with the exercise of that discretion. The High Court was of the view that all profits accumulated
